16 July 2014 Five New Species, One New Name, and Transfers in Neotropical Mistletoes (Loranthaceae), Miscellaneous Notes, 61–68
Job Kuijt
Author Affiliations +
Job Kuijt
649 Lost Lake Road, Victoria, British Columbia V9B 6E3, Canada. jobkuijt@uvic.ca
Novon: A J. for Botanical Nomenclature, 23(2):176-187 (2014). https://doi.org/10.3417/2012042

Abstract

New combinations are here proposed for Maracanthus costaricensis (Kuijt) Kuijt [≡ Oryctina costaricensis Kuijt] and Passovia pedunculata (Jacq.) Kuijt [≡ Loranthus pedunculatus Jacq.]. Five new species of Loranthaceae from South America are also described and illustrated: Psittacanthus longiflorus Kuijt from Peru, Struthanthus cajamarcanus Kuijt from Peru, S. ophiostylus Kuijt from Peru, S. truncatus Kuijt from Colombia, and Tristerix divaricatus Kuijt from Peru. The name Passovia pedunculata is neotypified.

As part of ongoing studies on Neotropical Loranthaceae, additional novelties and nomenclatural changes have emerged. New combinations and names are proposed as well as the description of five new species from Colombia and Peru.

61. Transfer of Oryctina costaricensis to Maracanthus

Maracanthus costaricensis (Kuijt) Kuijt, comb. nov. Basionym: Oryctina costaricensis Kuijt, Novon 17(4): 476–478, figs. 1, 2. 2007. TYPE: Costa Rica. Puntarenas: Cantón de Osa, R. F. Golfo Dulce, Peninsula de Osa, Rancho Quemado, Sector Sureste, 8°40′50″N, 83°33′00″W, 250 m, 16 Sep. 1992, J. Marin & D. Marin 521 (holotype, UC; isotypes, CR not seen, INB not seen, MO).

Figure 1.

Psittacanthus longiflorus Kuijt. —A. Habit. —B. Flower. —C. Anther morphology, seen abaxially (left) and adaxially (right). Drawn from the holotype, V. Quipuscoa, A. Sagástegui, S. Leiva & M. Bejarano 1322 (NY).

The Neotropical genera Maracanthus Kuijt and Oryctina Tiegh. are both characterized by indeterminate inflorescences bearing pairs of bracteolate, sessile, hexamerous flowers (Kuijt, 1976, 1981). Especially in Oryctina, the flowers are exceedingly small, and in the recently discovered species O. atrolineata Kuijt, the inflorescence is reduced to a single flower (Kuijt, 2003). When O. costaricensis, from the Osa Peninsula in Costa Rica, was first described (Kuijt, 2007), it was the only Mesoamerican representative of the genus. A review of the relevant species in Oryctina has convinced me that this species was misplaced, and it is now placed in the genus Maracanthus.

Oryctina was initially separated from Oryctanthus (Griseb.) Eichler by its lack of bracteoles (or prophylls) and its dioecy; however, both these features were subsequently shown to be in error (Kuijt, 1981). Prophyllar bracteoles in Oryctina are exceedingly small, as are its floral organs, and at least two species, Oryctina subaphylla Rizzini and O. scabrida (Eichler) Tiegh., are monoecious. However, especially through subsequently described species (Kuijt, 2000), there is no doubt that Oryctina represents a valid genus.

The distinctions between Oryctina and Maracanthus are based on floral characters. The prophyllar bracteoles of Oryctina are minute and have a more or less smooth, rounded dorsal surface; the anthers are sessile and have either two or four locules and no connectival prominence is present. Species that correspond to this are from central Brazil, with the exception of O. atrolineata from Guyana. The prophylls in Maracanthus, in contrast, are quite prominent, with a distinctive, carinate dorsal surface; the anthers are dorsifixed and borne on evident filaments (although short in M. badilloi (G. Ferrari) Kuijt), each bearing a very prominent connectival horn. In two of the known species, M. chlamydatus (Rizzini) Kuijt and M. pedunculatus Kuijt, functional styles terminate in a distinct, capitate stigma; in the remaining species, M. badilloi, the stigma is less evident (cf. Kuijt, 1987, as M. pusillus Kuijt). The three species heretofore known are all from Venezuela and Colombia. In O. costaricensis the prophyllar bracteoles are large, to 1 mm, and carinate; distinct filaments are present, and the connectival horn, especially of the shorter stamen series, is quite prominent, to 0.5 mm and to lengths equivalent to the anther sacs (Kuijt, 2007: 478, fig. 2b). The Costa Rican species corresponds in these features to Maracanthus rather than Oryctina, and therefore the proposed new combination M. costaricensis is supported. Geographically, the Costa Rican species would seem to be part of the Colombian–Venezuelan group.

Figure 2.

Struthanthus cajamarcanus Kuijt. —A. Habit of fruiting plant. —B. Triad, seen abaxially. —C. Lateral inflorescence unit with two triads on lower inflorescence. Drawn from the holotype, C. Díaz, S. Flores & W. Córdova 10695 (UC).

62. A New Name for Passovia stelis

Passovia pedunculata (Jacq.) Kuijt, comb. nov. Basionym: Loranthus pedunculatus Jacq., Enum. Syst. Pl. 18. 1760. TYPE: Panama. Panamá: Arraijan, seaside W of Vera Cruz, sea level, 30 May 1978, B. Hammel 3298 (neotype, designated here, MO; isoneotype, UC).

Loranthus sessilis Jacq., Enum. Syst. Pl. 18. 1760, nom. inval., syn. nov.

Phthirusa amazonensis Weir, Dept. Bull. U.S.D.A. 1380: 95. 1926, syn. nov. TYPE: Brazil, Rio Beni, Riberalta, 30 Sep. 1923, J. R. Weir s.n. (holotype, US-1199133; isotype, US-1199134).

Passovia stelis (L.) Kuijt, Pl. Div. Evol. 129(2): 205–206. 2011, syn. nov. Basionym: Loranthus stelis L., Sp. Pl., ed 2. 437. 1762, non Loranthus stelis G. Forst., Fl. Ins. Austral. 25. 1786. Phthirusa stelis (L.) Kuijt, Taxon 43(2): 193. 1994. TYPE: Corresponds to the type of Passovia pedunculata (Jacq.) Kuijt, neotype designated in Kuijt & Kellogg (1996: 50). (cf. Kuijt & Kellogg [1996] for complete synonymy.)

Passovia jamaicensis (Krug & Urb.) Kuijt, Smithsonian Contr. Bot. 98: 479. 2012, syn. nov. Basionym: Phthirusa jamaicensis Krug & Urb., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 24: 15. 1897. TYPE: Jamaica, s.d., Purdie s.n. (holotype, K).

After altogether too many changes in the nomenclature of what most recently has been called Passovia stelis, a hopefully final change is mandated by the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (McNeill et al., 2012). It appears that there are two more taxon names in Jacquin's (1760) Enumeratio that are indistinguishable from and predate the appearance of Loranthus stelis L. by two years, L. pedunculatus and L. sessilis. For both, as in the historical literature, the diagnosis is exceedingly short. The only difference indicated by Jacquin is that the flowers (presumably triads) were pedunculate (in L. pedunculatus) or sessile (in L. sessilis), representing a variable feature in the species. A more detailed description was provided three years later (Jacquin, 1763) in which the collection locality of both names was stated to be in the area of Cartago, Venezuela. The only common, triadic, more or less racemose, small-flowered member of Loranthaceae along the Venezuelan coast is what is presently known as P. stelis. The question whether either (or both) of Jacquin's species correspond to the most common coastal Venezuelan species can be resolved technically only through the study of their type specimens. But that is precisely the problem, as it has been virtually impossible to locate and authenticate Jacquin's specimens (D'Arcy, 1970). Several of the comments in Jacquin's treatment (1763: 98–99) tend to confirm this identity, especially when mentioning “Filamenta sunt duplo petalis breviora” and “… ramos … radiculas emittunt crassas teretesque …,” which are conditions found locally only in Passovia H. Karst. Both names, L. pedunculatus and L. sessilis, are here regarded as belonging to the same variable species, thus there remains the task of selecting a neotype. In order to simplify the situation as much as possible, I herewith designate the type of L. stelis (MO neotype, Hammel 3298) as the type of both of the other species.

63. New Synonyms within Passovia

Passovia pyrifolia (Kunth) Tiegh., Bull. Soc. Bot. France 42: 172. 1895. Basionym: Loranthus pyrifolius Kunth, Nov. Gen. Sp. Pl. (quarto ed.) 3: 441. 1818 [1820]. Struthanthus pyrifolius (Kunth) G. Don, Gen. Hist. 3: 413. 1834. Phthirusa pyrifolia (Kunth) Eichler, Fl. Bras. 5(2): 63, tab. 17. 1868. TYPE: [Venezuela.] “Crescit in calidis Prov. Popayanensis, prope Cartago,” Fl. Oct., A. Bonpland s.n. (holotype, P).

Phthirusa lepidobotrys (Griseb.) Eichler, Fl. Bras. (Martius) 5(2): 334. 1866, syn. nov. Basyonym: Loranthus lepidobotrys Griseb., Fl. Brit. W.I. [Grisebach] 311. 1860. TYPE: Jamaica, 1850, R. C. Alexander s.n. (holotype, GOET-005495; isotype, K-567886).

Phthirusa brasiliensis Weir, Dept. Bull. U.S.D.A. 1380: 95–96. 1926, syn. nov. TYPE: Brazil. Amazonas: Urucurituba, Madeira River, on Hevea brasiliensis, 28 Aug. 1923, J. R. Weir s.n. (holotype, US-119132).

Phthirusa lepidobotrys has in the past been regarded as a Jamaican endemic but appears to be no different from the common continental populations of P. pyrifolia. The type of P. brasiliensis has hitherto escaped my attention but corresponds to the same species.

64. Psittacanthus longiflorus, a New Species from Peru

Psittacanthus longiflorus Kuijt, sp. nov. TYPE: Peru. Amazonas: Prov. Chachapoyas, Distr. Leymebamba, a 2 km de la Laguna de los Cóndores, ruta hacia Leymebamba, borde de camino, 2700–2950 m, 18 Aug. 1998 (fl.), V. Quipuscoa, A. Sagástegui, S. Leiva & M. Bejarano 1322 (holotype, NY; isotypes, F, UC). Figure 1.

Diagnosis. 

Psittacanthus longiflorus is distinguished from all its congeners by the length of its flowers (to 17 cm), its coarsely dentate calyculus, and its conspicuously spurred pollen sacs.

Shoots determinate, each innovation to 5 cm and terminating in a whorl of 3 leaves, the apex aborting; stem internodes slightly 3-angled when young, becoming terete in age. Leaf blade to 9 × 2.5 cm, narrowly elliptical to nearly oblong, apex rounded, base acutely tapering into petiole, ca. 7 mm; venation pinnate; lower midrib prominently raised. Inflorescence a double dyad; inflorescence peduncle 5 mm; dyad peduncle 4 mm; floral pedicel 6 mm; cupule 4 mm wide, with acute apex; flowers to 17 cm, of which the ovary is 6 mm, with coarsely dentate calyculus; corolla tube reflexed; stamens 2 cm, the base attached 3 cm below the petal apex; anthers dorsifixed, at 2 non-overlapping heights, each 9 mm, the apex rounded, the base of the pollen sacs conspicuously spurred, acute, the inner spurs nearly 2 mm; filament attached dorsally just above the anther base; style nearly as long as the petals; stigma clavate. Fruit unknown.

Distribution and ecology. 

Psittacanthus longiflorus is known only from Peru, Amazonas.

IUCN Red List category. 

Since the new species is known from a single collection, its conservation status is assessed as Data Deficient (DD), according to IUCN (2001) standards.

Discussion. 

Psittacanthus longiflorus may be confused with Aetanthus macranthus (Hook.) Kuijt because of its unusually long flowers (to 17 cm), the longest known for Psittacanthus Mart., but its dorsifixed anthers in two non-overlapping series as well as the rounded, non-acicular, anther apices place it in Psittacanthus. The species is unique within its genus because of its remarkable flower length as well as its conspicuously spurred anther bases. The length of the flower certainly indicates its pendent natural position as well as its pollination by hummingbirds.

65. Struthanthus cajamarcanus, a New Species from Peru

Struthanthus cajamarcanus Kuijt, sp. nov. TYPE: Peru. Cajamarca: San Ignacio, San José de Lourdes, El Crucero, 1000–1100 m, bosque intervenido, 9 June 1999 (fr.), C. Díaz, S. Flores & W. Córdova 10695 (holotype, UC; isotype, MO). Figure 2.

Diagnosis. 

Struthanthus cajamarcanus differs from all its congeners by the compound structure of its lowest inflorescence units and the marginally dentate bracteoles, and from most by the sharply acute leaf apex and the pedunculate triads placed at right angles to the inflorescence axis.

Glabrous, rigid plants; dioecious; stem internodes 2.5–3.5 cm, terete, smooth, without lenticels; epicortical roots apparently lacking. Leaf blade to 6 × 3.5 cm, lanceolate, apex acute, with needle-like tip, base obtuse to acute, margin smooth and leathery; petiole to 1 cm, discrete; venation pinnate, the midvein running into the apex and keeled on the abaxial surface. Inflorescences 1 per leaf axil, to 6.5 cm; axis quadrangular, unbranched, except for the lowest lateral units, beyond which 4 to 6 pairs of triads extend; lowest 2 lateral inflorescence units composed of a 4-mm-long stalk usually bearing an acicular bract midway and 2 regular triads at the apex (3 or 4 triads in vigorous inflorescences); triad peduncles 3 mm, placed at right angles on inflorescence axis; each bract and bracteole 1.5–2 mm, distinct, acute, acicular in the bract; flowers not seen. Fruit 4 × 3.5 mm, ellipsoid, green; calyculus inconspicuous; bracteoles conspicuous, with marginal tooth near the base.

Distribution and ecology. 

Struthanthus cajamarcanus is known only from the type locality in Cajamarca, Peru.

IUCN Red List category. 

Since the new species is known from a single collection, its conservation status is assessed as Data Deficient (DD), according to IUCN (2001) standards.

Discussion. 

Given that no flowers are available in the type specimen, it is presently impossible to be certain whether this remarkable plant belongs to Struthanthus or Passovia. If the new species turns out to have bisexual flowers, it must be placed in the latter. However, the similarities of S. cajamarcanus to S. marginatus (Desr.) Blume, from eastern and southern Brazil, strongly suggest that the present taxonomic placement is correct. Nonetheless, S. marginatus is a more robust species with sinuous, long stems that bear epicortical roots and does not have the curious basal inflorescence units of S. cajamarcanus. It should be noted that S. marginatus f. paniculata Eichler does occasionally form complex branched inflorescences (Eichler, 1868, fig. 22).

66. Struthanthus ophiostylus, a New Species from Peru

Struthanthus ophiostylus Kuijt, sp. nov. TYPE. Peru. Loreto: Mishuyacu, near Iquitos, 100 m, May–June 1930 (fl.), G. Klug 1562 (holotype, US). Figure 3.

Figure 3.

Struthanthus ophiostylus Kuijt. —A. Habit. —B. Inflorescence, post-anthesis. —C. Individual flower, enlarged. Drawn from the holotype, G. Klug 1562 (US).

Diagnosis. 

Struthanthus ophiostylus is distinguished from its congeners by its unusually large leaves (to 16 × 8 cm), and especially by its short inflorescence bearing only 4 pedunculate triads; within South American Struthanthus it is distinguished from all other species by its conspicuously contorted styles.

Plants robust, sparsely branched, glabrous; stem internodes 5–7 cm × 3 mm, when leaf-bearing, straight, terete. Leaf blade to 16 × 8 cm, lanceolate, apex acute, somewhat attenuate, base obtuse to truncate; petiole 1 cm, distinct; venation pinnate, the midrib strongly marked and flanked by nearly perpendicular lateral veins; adaxial surface shiny. Inflorescences axillary, 1 or several per leaf axil, each ca. 8 mm, indeterminate, consisting of 2 pairs of triads; inflorescence and triad peduncles and floral pedicels (of both lateral and median flowers) 1–1.5 mm, terete; bracts and bracteoles caducous; base of inflorescence subtended by brown, corky crater; ovary as long as floral pedicel; ± cylindrical. Flower with the calyculus smooth; petals and stamens not known; style 2 mm, strongly coiled; stigma capitate, papillate, distinct. Fruit unknown.

Distribution and ecology. 

Struthanthus ophiostylus is known only from the type collection from Loreto, Peru.

IUCN Red List category. 

Since the new species is known from a single collection, its conservation status is assessed as Data Deficient (DD), according to IUCN (2001) standards.

Discussion. 

Struthanthus ophiostylus appears to be a rare species, as it has not, as far as I know, been collected again since 1930. It is unmistakable because of its combination of very large leaves and small inflorescences and especially its greatly convoluted (strongly coiled) styles. Such styles are now known from two genera in South American Loranthaceae, Peristethium Tiegh. (Kuijt, 2012) and Struthanthus. The former genus is characterized by determinate inflorescences, perhaps always at least some monads, and particularly by the chaffy bracts that subtend young inflorescences. None of these features are present in the new species, warranting its assignment to Struthanthus. In Mexico, some species of Struthanthus and Cladocolea Tiegh. also show similar stylar convolutions (Kuijt, 1975a, 1975b). There, as well as in South America, the biological significance of coiled styles is a mystery. It should be noted that the styles do not straighten out, but are dropped in the coiled condition after anthesis. Stylar convolutions in all these cases are always most strongly expressed in the female flower, and the type of S. ophiostylus is likely to be male.

67. Struthanthus truncatus, a New Species from Colombia

Struthanthus truncatus Kuijt, sp. nov. TYPE: Colombia. Chocó: Río Atrato near Río Sucio, seasonally inundated swamp, less than 100 m, 16 Jan. 1974 (fl.) A. Gentry 9258 (holotype, MO-2464246; isotype, UC). Figure 4.

Figure 4.

Struthanthus truncatus Kuijt. —A. Habit, with young inflorescences. —B. Inflorescence. —C. Male flower bud. —D. Style and two stamen-petal complexes, seen adaxially. Drawn from the isotype, A. Gentry 9258 (UC).

Diagnosis. 

Large, sparsely branched plants reminiscent of Struthanthus orbicularis (Kunth) Eichler, differing from it by the broadly obovate leaves with truncate apex and a small, recurved apiculus, and the sessile anthers with a small connectival horn at apex.

Plants glabrous, scandent, dioecious, with epicortical roots emerging from the stems and probably from the base; stem internodes to 7 cm, terete, smooth, lacking lenticels. Leaf blade up to 5(−5.5) × 4.5–5(−5.5) cm, broadly obovate, apex truncate, with minute, abaxially reflexed apiculus, base acute to nearly obtuse; petiole to 1 cm, distinct; venation pinnate; midrib evident, raised, running into the apex. Male inflorescence at least 5 cm; axis strongly quadrangular; peduncle to 5 mm, followed by at least 5 pairs of nearly sessile triads with broad, caducous bracts and minute, acute bracteoles. Flowers greenish cream; male flower buds 6 mm, clavate, sessile, hexamerous; petals narrow and pointed, 5 mm; calyculus irregularly dentate; anthers sessile, ellipsoid, with prominent connectival horn, placed at 2 overlapping heights; sterile style slender, 4 mm; stigma undifferentiated; ovary 1 mm. Female plants and fruit unknown.

Distribution and ecology. 

Struthanthus truncatus is known from the type locality, from the Chocó region in Colombia. The species may also have been collected from the departments of Cauca and Putumayo.

IUCN Red List category. 

Since the new species is reliably known from a single collection, its conservation status is assessed as Data Deficient (DD), according to IUCN (2001) standards.

Discussion. 

The remarkable leaf shape clearly distinguishes Struthanthus truncatus as a distinct species. Moreover, the sessile anthers in this new taxon also represent an exceedingly unusual feature in the genus. Struthanthus truncatus seems to be related to S. orbicularis, which is a large and common species ranging from southern Mexico to the Bolivian Amazon. Struthanthus orbicularis has much larger inflorescences, a different leaf shape, quadrangular internodes, evident filaments on the non-sessile stamens, and the young leaves function as prehensile organs (Kuijt, 1964).

Two more specimens from Colombia are listed below as possible paratypes. They present, at least sometimes, a similar leaf shape, but are much larger plants, thus I cannot be certain whether they are conspecific with the new taxon. The first one from Cauca has inflorescences at least 15 cm long, bearing at least eight pairs of (female) flowers, with triads on peduncles 2.5 mm long, and all flowers on pedicels 3.5 mm long. The second (male) specimen from Putumayo bears even larger leaves, the blades being up to 9 × 6 cm, and having an apex, at least sometimes with a distinct 2-mm-long tooth; its inflorescences reach at least 12 cm in length and bear up to 13 pairs of triads; both flowers and triads are completely sessile.

Paratypes. 

COLOMBIA. Cauca: Quebrada across Río Naya from El Plastico, inundated streamside, 3°10′N, 77°22′W, 20 m, 23 Feb. 1983 (♀ fl.), A. Gentry & A. Juncosa 40600 (MO). Putumayo: Mocoa y los alrededores al Norte, 750–850 m, 3–7 Dec. 1942 (♂ fl.), R. E. Schultes & C. E. Smith 2056 (MO).

68. Tristerix divaricatus, a New Species from Peru

Tristerix divaricatus Kuijt, sp. nov. TYPE. Peru. Cajamarca: San Ignacio, San José de Lourdes, slopes of Cerro Picorana, 4°58′S, 78°53′1″W, 2500–2540 m, 5 Dec. 1998 (fl., fr.), J. Campos, L. Zurita & M. Camizan 5944 (holotype, UC; isotype, MO). Figure 5.

Figure 5.

Tristerix divaricatus Kuijt. —A. Habit. —B. Stamen, seen adaxially. —C. Fruit, pedicel, and foliar bract. —D. Embryo, showing fused cotyledonary blades (below) and haustorial disk with papilla (above). Drawn from the holotype, J. Campos, L. Zurita & M. Camizan 5944 (UC).

Diagnosis. 

Tristerix divaricatus is reminiscent of T. longibracteatus (Desr.) Barlow & Wiens, but differs from it primarily by its lax, racemose inflorescence with spreading rather than erect, clustered flowers and its long pedicels, and also by its much smaller fruit lacking the apical, conical prominence characteristic of T. longibracteatus.

Plants sympodial, glabrous; stem internodes 2–5 cm, keeled to somewhat quadrangular. Leaves to 5 × 2.5 cm, broadly lanceolate, the apex acute; venation pinnate, the lower midrib keeled. Inflorescence terminal, racemose, bearing 6 to 8 flowers, in pairs or in whorls of 4; floral pedicel 1 cm; floral bract 10–20 × 4–5 mm, lanceolate, cuneate and acute; flower buds to 7 cm, 3 mm thick below, the terminal 1.5 cm expanded to 4 mm, apex tapered but ultimately rounded. Flowers erect, with the calyculus shallowly dentate; petals 5; stamens nearly isomorphic; filaments 17 mm; anthers 10 mm, with filament attachment in a deep dorsal groove, 3 mm from the anther base; ovary 4 × 4 mm, ± straight; style straight; stigma weakly differentiated, slightly notched and very finely papillate. Fruit 9 × 9 mm, globular, the calyculus slightly dentate.

Distribution and ecology. 

Tristerix divaricatus is known only from the type locality in Cajamarca, Peru.

IUCN Red List category. 

Since the new species is known from a single collection, its conservation status is assessed as Data Deficient (DD), according to IUCN (2001) standards.

Discussion. 

The extremely open and extended inflorescence of Tristerix divaricatus gives this species a distinctive aspect that has no counterpart elsewhere in the genus. Nevertheless, there is little doubt that it is closely related to T. longibracteatus and T. peytonii Kuijt. Tristerix divaricatus differs most strikingly from T. longibracteatus in its inflorescence, both in the elongation of the main axis and in the length of the individual floral pedicels, but also in having keeled or quadrangular internodes, globular fruits that lack the conical prominence characteristic of T. longibracteatus fruits, and a much more prominent calyculus (Kuijt, 1988, fig. 10c). The flowers of T. longibracteatus stand more or less erect (cf. Kuijt, 1986, fig. 10a), while those of T. divaricatus are perpendicular to the inflorescence axis. Tristerix peytonii differs from the new species in having longer (up to 8 cm), distinctly arched buds, the ovary twice as long as broad, and the bud apex showing a distinct, slight petal dimorphism (Kuijt, 1988, fig. 9b). In contrast, T. divaricatus has buds to 7 cm long and more or less straight, an equidimensional ovary, and no petal dimorphism at the bud apex. The collection localities of the two species are about 1200 km apart, with T. peytonii being a narrow endemic of the Cuzco area in Peru.

The mature embryo of Tristerix divaricatus is 6 mm long and closely resembles that of T. longibracteatus (cf. Kuijt, 1982, fig. 47). The radicular pole consists of a broad haustorial cushion with a smooth face and the sides densely covered by innumerable, prominent papillae. In contrast to that of T. longibracteatus, the papillar haustorial cushion is set off sharply from the attached cotyledonary petioles. Otherwise as generally occurring in the genus, the blades of the cotyledons themselves are completely fused without showing a suture and terminate into an acute tip. The cotyledonary petioles remain separate, with the eventual first leaves emerging in between them; thus, the germination pattern is cryptocotylar. The embryo is surrounded by a relatively small amount of endosperm, from which the haustorial cushion emerges. The massive, fused cotyledons appear to have taken over much of the storage function of the endosperm, a developmental trait, which ultimately, in an independent, parallel fashion, has resulted in the complete loss of endosperm in other Loranthaceae such as Aetanthus (Eichler) Engl. and Psittacanthus (Kuijt, 2009).

Acknowledgments.

I am obliged to Christiane Anderson, University of Michigan, for help with Grisebach types. John K. Boggan (US) kindly drew to my attention the two Weir names covered in Notes No. 62 and 63, images of which were sent to me by Ingrid Pol-Yin (US). The Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada is acknowledged for past financial support.
